Site: Dawson Post Office Third Avenue and King Street
Description: Two-storey wooden building with a three-storey hexagonal tower . The building incorporates post-office and a telegraph annex

A two-storey neoclassical building , built with fir and cedar imported to the Yukon from British Columbia . The design features elements used elsewhere in Fuller 's Dawson building program , including pediments , columns , axial symmetry , and gentle relief

The building was designed in a Tudor/Gothic Revival style . A classic example of armoury design , Mewata has features deliberately bringing to mind a medieval fortress or castle , including four square corner towers , four smaller six sided towers , and buttresses with turrets and a crenellated roofline
large Neo-Gothic style structure with a low-pitched gable roof on a flat site faced by mature trees within an area of containing light industry , and adjacent to a residential area
Housing Le Régiment de Maisonneuve , this Gothic Revival armoury ` s two-dimensional façade with a low-pitched gable roof is pressed up against its urban streetscape

Site: Côte des Neiges Armoury 4185 Chemin de la Côte des Neiges ,
Description: On a treed site on the southwest perimeter of Mount Royal Park , this Châteauesque structure houses The Royal Canadian Hussars ( Montreal ) ; 2nd Field Regiment , Royal Canadian Artillery

This centrally located Neo-Gothic style fortress like building with a low-pitched gable roof is in a modern residential neighbourhood adjacent to the Regina Exhibition Grounds , Organizations that use the armoury include : Regina units of 38th Brigade Group : 10th Field Regiment , Royal Canadian Artillery , Royal Regina Rifles , 16th ( Saskatchewan ) Service Battalion , 16th Medical Company , cadet corps and the Military Museum of Saskatchewan
centrally located , symmetrical Neo-Gothic style building with a steeply pitched gable roof

designed by architects McCarter and Nairne , the massive , low-massed , asymmetrical , concrete Neo-Gothic style structure with a fortified appearance is as a Class A Heritage Building in downtown Vancouver housing The Seaforth Highlanders of Canada

Site: Confederation Building ( Ottawa ) , Wellington Street at Bank Street

Description: Beaux-Arts extension of Post Office Building by David Ewart
